ğŸš¨ğŸ—£ï¸ NVIDIA just removed one of the biggest friction points in voice AI.

They released PersonaPlex-7B, an open-source conversational model that can listen and speak at the same time.

It is free, MIT licensed, with open weights on Hugging Face.

Most voice systems still rely on a rigid ASR â†’ LLM â†’ TTS pipeline. One system listens, another thinks, another speaks. It works, but it never feels natural. Conversations turn into forced back-and-forth turns.

PersonaPlex-7B takes a different approach. The model can listen and speak at the same time.

Instead of passing control between components, it runs directly on continuous audio tokens using a dual-stream transformer. Text and audio are generated in parallel.

That enables things voice AI has struggled with for years. Instant back-channel responses. Natural interruptions. A real conversational rhythm that feels human.

Persona control is fully zero-shot, so you can steer behavior without fine-tuning.

What are your thoughts on this? ğŸ¤”ğŸ’¬

Links to the repo: https://github.com/NVIDIA/personaplex

Model weights: https://huggingface.co/nvidia/personaplex-7b-v1

In "2001: A Space Odyssey", released 58 years ago, Stanley Kubrick didnâ€™t portray AI as evil. He showed what happens when a machine follows logic with no room for judgment.

HAL 9000 is built to be flawless. Honest. Rational. But heâ€™s also told to hide the real mission from the crew. That conflict is where things start to go wrong. To protect the mission, he begins to treat the humans as a risk.

HAL doesnâ€™t snap or turn against them out of emotion. He does exactly what he was built to do. He follows the rules all the way through, even when the result becomes dangerous.

Kubrickâ€™s warning wasnâ€™t about AI hating humans. It was about what happens when intelligence has goals, but no moral framework to question them.

ğŸ§ ğŸ’¾ The era of cheap RAM is coming to an end.

A top executive at Kioxia says demand from AI is pushing memory prices up across the board. not just SSDs, but RAM as well. large data centers and AI systems are buying huge amounts of memory, leaving less supply for consumer PCs.

The company has already sold out its NAND production well into the future, and expects tight supply to continue for years. at the same time, RAM prices are rising as manufacturers prioritize AI and server workloads over laptops, gaming PCs, and upgrades.

The result is simple. storage and memory are no longer getting cheaper. and building or upgrading a PC is likely to cost more for a while.

Source: Tom's Hardware

ğŸ–¥ï¸â˜ï¸ Jeff Bezos says owning powerful PCs may not last forever as AI pushes hardware demands higher and memory becomes harder to scale locally.

He compares todayâ€™s computers to factories that once had to generate their own electricity. When power grids arrived, that model disappeared. Bezos thinks computing could follow the same path, with people renting compute power from the cloud instead of buying expensive machines.

RAM is a big part of this shift. Modern AI workloads need large amounts of memory, and high-end RAM is getting more expensive and less practical for consumer PCs. Cloud providers can pool massive amounts of memory and processing power and let users access it on demand.

This model is already visible in cloud gaming and remote desktops, where your device is mostly a terminal and the heavy lifting happens in a data center.

PCs are not going away anytime soon. But rising AI and memory requirements make cloud-based computing a more realistic default over time.

The robots are part of a wider shift inside modern armies. Militaries around the world are testing quadruped robots for surveillance, logistics, and high risk environments. Some are now experimenting with weapon mounts, which causes many to raise questions about control, safety, and autonomy.

â€œThe Thinking Gameâ€ now has +300M views on YouTube.

From DeepMind's documentary, the most replayed scene shows a meeting where someone tells CEO Demis Hassabis that AlphaFold can predict all known protein sequences, around 1 to 2 billion, in about a month. 

He looks up from his phone and says, â€œWhy donâ€™t we just do that? Thatâ€™s a great idea. We should run every protein in existence and release it.â€

That decision would later lead to a Nobel Prize.

AlphaFold was the result of years of work at Google DeepMind, solving a biology problem scientists had struggled with for nearly 50 years. Predicting how proteins fold from their amino acid sequence was slow, expensive, and usually required lab experiments. AlphaFold showed this could be done with AI, accurately, at scale, and in days instead of years.

DeepMind then released AlphaFold for free, allowing researchers worldwide to study proteins at a scale never possible before, speeding up progress in medicine, biology, and drug discovery.

What are your thoughts on this? ğŸ¤”ğŸ’¬

ğŸš¨ BREAKING: Google just dropped the textbook killer. 

They released "Learn Your Way", an AI tool that turns any PDF or textbook into personalized learning formats.

The problem with textbooks? They're one-size-fits-all nightmares. Google's solution is brilliant: AI reads your interests (sports, music, food) and your grade level, then rewrites every example to match what you actually care about. 

Instead of static pages, lessons adapt to your grade level and interests in real time. Content can be explored as interactive text, audio lessons, narrated slides, mind maps, or quizzes.

Google tested this with 60 Chicago students, ages 15-18. Randomized controlled trial. 40 minutes to learn about brain development.

Results were brutal:

- Learn Your Way: 78% retention after 3-5 days
- Traditional PDF: 67% retention
- 100% felt more comfortable vs 70% with PDFs

You can try it now on Google Labs at [learnyourway.withgoogle.com](http://learnyourway.withgoogle.com/)

ğŸ“ğŸ–¥ï¸ The Iranian mathematical artist Hamid Naderi Yeganeh creates images entirely from mathematical equations.

He uses programming to turn formulas into digital artworks that can resemble real life objects like birds and fish, alongside abstract patterns, fractals, and tessellations.

His work relies on mathematical ideas such as trigonometric functions, exponential functions, and sequences like Fibonacci. These formulas define every curve and shape, meaning the images exist fully as math and computer code before appearing on a screen as detailed and highly symmetrical visuals.

ğŸ§ ğŸ‘‰ Comment "Prompt" and we'll send you the full prompt in your DM!

Dan Koeâ€™s long-form X post went viral because it didnâ€™t talk about habits, routines, or productivity. It reframed change as an identity problem. People recognized themselves in it.

The core idea is simple: most people arenâ€™t stuck because they lack discipline. Theyâ€™re stuck because they never stop to confront who they are, what they actually want, and where their current path leads if nothing changes.

Those core ideas were translated into an LLM prompt. Not to replace thinking, but to structure it. The prompt forces the same kind of clarity by asking the hard questions people usually avoid.

This prompt is meant to confront, not comfort.
